articles.headline: Pursuing a Shipping Revolution as Big as His Airship
articles.snippet: Igor Pasternak is developing an airship called the Aeroscraft that could travel much faster than a cargo ship and carry much more than a cargo plane, but obstacles remain.
articles.abstract: Igor Pasternak is developing an airship called the Aeroscraft that could travel much faster than a cargo ship and carry much more than a cargo plane, but obstacles remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTEBELLO, Calif. — Somewhere beneath the graying shock of mad-professor hair, the dark circles under his eyes and the Russian-strained, cigarette-stained baritone, there remains in Igor Pasternak a boy with a dream.

articles.headline: For Guccifer, Hacking Was Easy. Prison Is Hard.
articles.snippet: Marcel-Lehel Lazar, whose pseudonym celebrated “the style of Gucci and the light of Lucifer,” rampaged through the email of rich Americans, showing the ease of going rogue online.
articles.abstract: Marcel-Lehel Lazar, whose pseudonym celebrated “the style of Gucci and the light of Lucifer,” rampaged through the email of rich Americans, showing the ease of going rogue online.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARAD, Romania — He reveled in tormenting members of the Bush family, Colin L. Powell and a host of other prominent Americans, and also in outfoxing the F.B.I. and the Secret Service, foiling their efforts to discover even his nationality, never mind his identity. Early this year, however, the elusive online outlaw known as Guccifer lost his cocky composure and began to panic.

articles.headline: Suit Accuses Banks of Role in Financing Terror Attacks
articles.snippet: More than 200 people filed the lawsuit in federal court, accusing the banks of helping to finance the violent activities through their ties to Iran, painting Wall Street as a sort of middleman of terror.
articles.abstract: More than 200 people filed the lawsuit in federal court, accusing the banks of helping to finance the violent activities through their ties to Iran, painting Wall Street as a sort of middleman of terror.
articles.lead_paragraph: A five-car convoy opened fire on a compound 30 miles south of Baghdad, a sneak attack that killed four American soldiers in one of the deadliest days in the Iraq war. A roadside bomb struck a United States military vehicle, severing part of a soldier’s head. And a militant group kidnapped and killed an American journalist, dumping him in the street after firing three shots into his chest.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: An Oklahoma Oilman’s Billion-Dollar Divorce
articles.snippet: After a secretive trial, Harold Hamm, the chief executive of Continental Resources, is paying one of the biggest divorce settlements in history.
articles.abstract: After a secretive trial, Harold Hamm, the chief executive of Continental Resources, is paying one of the biggest divorce settlements in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his nearly 50 years as an Oklahoma oil man, Harold Hamm has done everything on a huge scale. The chief executive and majority shareholder of Continental Resources, he owns the largest piece of the greatest oil discovery of our age, in the shale-rich plains of North Dakota. His net worth has been pegged at more than $18 billion by Forbes, making him the 24th richest man in the country.

articles.headline: It’s Official: Mormon Founder Had Up to 40 Wives
articles.snippet: The church made the disclosure about Joseph Smith to show transparency about its history at a time when some members have been feeling doubtful.
articles.abstract: The church made the disclosure about Joseph Smith to show transparency about its history at a time when some members have been feeling doubtful.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mormon leaders have acknowledged for the first time that the church’s founder and prophet, Joseph Smith, portrayed in church materials as a loyal partner to his loving spouse Emma, took as many as 40 wives, some already married and one only 14 years old.

articles.headline: 11 Years Later, Woman’s Death Is Tied to G.M. Ignition Defect
articles.snippet: The family of a woman who died when her General Motors car crashed in 2003 was never told her death was linked to a flaw that has killed at least 12 others.
articles.abstract: The family of a woman who died when her General Motors car crashed in 2003 was never told her death was linked to a flaw that has killed at least 12 others.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Conn. — Jean P. Averill warranted only a footnote.

articles.headline: More Transparency, More Pay for C.E.O.s
articles.snippet: As compensation consultants have become more popular in determining pay, chief executives’ paychecks have actually grown.
articles.abstract: As compensation consultants have become more popular in determining pay, chief executives’ paychecks have actually grown.
articles.lead_paragraph: “It’s very seldom that publishing compensation accomplishes much for the shareholders. No C.E.O. looks at a proxy statement and comes away saying, ‘I should be paid less.’ ”

articles.headline: The Book That Birthed a Potty-Mouth Genre Now Has a Sequel
articles.snippet: Four years later, Adam Mansbach is following up “Go the _ to Sleep” with “You Have to _ Eat.” In the interim, other writers have gotten in on on the act.
articles.abstract: Four years later, Adam Mansbach is following up “Go the _ to Sleep” with “You Have to _ Eat.” In the interim, other writers have gotten in on on the act.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Mansbach would like to apologize.

articles.headline: In New China, ‘Hostile’ West Is Still Derided
articles.snippet: Using language reminiscent of the Cold War, Chinese officials have voiced conspiracy theories accusing foreigners of plotting to weaken or overthrow the Communist Party.
articles.abstract: Using language reminiscent of the Cold War, Chinese officials have voiced conspiracy theories accusing foreigners of plotting to weaken or overthrow the Communist Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Even as his government was making red-carpet plans to host President Obama this week, the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, praised a young blogger whose writing is best known here for its anti-American vitriol.
